speaker: Guest
message: Good note to start with Amit, good intentions never make good policy or that's not the sufficient condition anyways. So yeah, let's go back to what these schemes are. And each of these three levels also earn some money. So by these three levels, you mean center state, center state and the local governments, right? So now, as it happens, the amount that these governments spend is always more than the amount that they earn. And because governments are not households or companies, they can still survive, even though they run deficits. So what do they do to make up for this deficit? One they take debts. So you have foreign debts, you also have debts from one government to the other. And the other way that governments engage is by supporting some other level of government. So how that happens in India is, so now we have the state government, state government will get some money, which is something like a cash transfer, which is in public finance

speaker: Amit Varma
message: literature, it is called general purpose from the central government from the union government.

speaker: Guest
message: So that is just like I am giving you cash, you can do whatever you want to do with it. So now, this type of thing is formulaic based. So that is what is called a centrally sponsored scheme. So again, from public finance literature, the objective of such a type of transfer is to ensure minimum standards of services in these particular areas are met. speaker: Amit Varma
message: So that is about centrally sponsored schemes. And states therefore have no option but to use the amount allocated for say Swachh Bharat on Swachh Bharat initiatives, they can't decide that hey, locally these issues are more important and therefore we will spend on these instead.

message: Yeah, that's a good question. So basically, this very much comes from this idea of a planned economy and that someone can direct from Delhi that how should India be governed. What is a speech if it doesn't announce 10 new schemes, right? It doesn't make cut, it's not very popular. So that's the whole idea why Union governments want to announce a whole host of schemes. Now, earlier in around 1969, etc, when we were in the planned period, still pretty much in the planned period, that was the time when the Union government started sort of increasing the number of schemes, which are called centrally sponsored schemes. So combine these two central sector and centrally sponsored schemes, these sort of started taking priority and these started proliferating. So there is a Chaturvedi committee, there is a Sarkaria committee, there is Punchi commission, all these commissions basically said the same thing, that central government can't do this, you can't run so many schemes for no reason. What you need to do is there are certain critical, critical areas in which you definitely need to ensure minimum standards, which I said, like health, education, these are critical areas which have interstate externalities, right, the impact of those are felt across India.
